review.title: Exploring the efficacy of molecular fragments of different complexity in computational SAR modeling
review.abstract: An important first step in computational SAR modeling is to transform the compounds into a representation that can be processed by predictive modeling techniques. This is typically a feature vector where each feature indicates the presence or absence of a molecular fragment. While the traditional approach to SAR modeling employed size restricted fingerprints derived from path fragments, much research in recent years focussed on mining more complex graph based fragments. Today, there seems to be a growing consensus in the data mining community that these more expressive fragments should be more useful. We question this consensus and show experimentally that fragments of low complexity, i.e. sequences, perform better than equally large sets of more complex ones, an effect we explain by pairwise correlation among fragments and the ability of a fragment set to encode compounds from different classes distinctly. The size restriction on these sets is based on ordering the fragments by class-correlation scores. In addition, we also evaluate the effects of using a significance value instead of a length restriction for path fragments and find a significant reduction in the number of features with little loss in performance.

metadata.title: Exploring the efficacy of molecular fragments of different complexity in computational SAR modeling

sections.heading: III. APPROACH
sections.text: We use substructures that correlate with one of two target classes (e.g. active and inactive) - and therefore distinguish between the two. Techniques exist for the degradation of top-k substructures according to convex measurements such as χ2 or Information Gain, while large portions of the search space are still truncated. Similar search strategies can be used to find all substructures with a score above a user-defined threshold. Please note that we only use χ2 in this work, as previous work has shown that this leads to better results than the use of information gain [15]. With regard to chemical substructures, there are three very well-studied types of substructures, namely: LG subgraphics that are the most meaningful, but expensive for mine; LT subtrees can represent anything but cycles; LS subsequences that are least expressive LLLLLV-V-V LV-V-V LLLV-V-V-V-V-V LLLLLV-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-LV-V-V-LLV-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-LLLLLLV-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-LLLV-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-LLLLLLLLV-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-LLLLLLLLLLLLV-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-LV-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-V-LLLLLV-V-V-V-V-V-V-V

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: We have conducted an empirical evaluation to gain insights into the reasons for the superiority of sequencers in molecular fragments as characteristics for classification, compared to complex ones. We find that the reason lies in the greater variety of sequences that lead to a more distinctive encoding of instances that effectively require better representation by the classifiers. [...] The number of fragments used is increased. [...] The worst score for fragments that have been mined with three different significance thresholds, and as length limited paths to work with. A linear way of improving the encoding is to increase the number of fragments used. However, our experiments show that there is a need for a much greater number of trees / graphics as sequences. Since these structures are also more expensive than enumeration, this leads to enormous complexity.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
sections.text: We thank Kurt De Grave for his invaluable help in compiling this manuscript. Albrecht Zimmermann was supported at the time of writing by the Fonds Wetenschappelijk Onderzoek (FWO).

referenceMentions.context: The graph mining community, on the other hand [1], approaches the construction of fragments slightly differently and while the differences are subtle, they can have significant effects.

In this paper, we build on earlier work [2] that aimed at generalizing the existing fingerprinting approach and explore how to derive the molecular fragments on which to base generalized fingerprints in a predictive setting.
They are decomposed into sets of (potentially overlapping) fragments and the similarity of any two molecules evaluated comparing their respective fragments using kernel functions [3].
A variety of different fragments has been used in the literature, from paths/walks [4], [2], [5], via fragments with branches (trees) [6], to those with cycles (graphs) [7], [8], [9], [10].

metadata.abstractText: An important first step in computational SAR modeling is to transform the compounds into a representation that can be processed by predictive modeling techniques. This is typically a feature vector where each feature indicates the presence or absence of a molecular fragment. While the traditional approach to SAR modeling employed size restricted fingerprints derived from path fragments, much research in recent years focussed on mining more complex graph based fragments. Today, there seems to be a growing consensus in the data mining community that these more expressive fragments should be more useful. We question this consensus and show experimentally that fragments of low complexity, i.e. sequences, perform better than equally large sets of more complex ones, an effect we explain by pairwise correlation among fragments and the ability of a fragment set to encode compounds from different classes distinctly. The size restriction on these sets is based on ordering the fragments by class-correlation scores. In addition, we also evaluate the effects of using a significance value instead of a length restriction for path fragments and find a significant reduction in the number of features with little loss in performance.
